who is succeeded after a few months by John XXIII

note: Battle of Tannenberg: the Lithuanian-Polish army defeats the Teutonic Order. 260 
title: Death of Emperor Rupert III: Charles IV’s son, Sigismund of Luxembourg, is elected king of Bohemia, but Jan Hus and his followers rebel against him. Death of Martin I of Aragon: his succession is disputed. Pierre d’Ailly (1351–1420) composes the treatise Imago mundi: Christopher Columbus, decades later, buys and annotates a copy of its first
Conference of Caspe: Ferdinand of Trastamara (Castile) becomes king of Aragon
The Limbourg brothers illuminate the manuscript of the Très Riches Heures for Duke John of Berry
Death of Henry IV of England: his son Henry V is crowned king
An ecumenical council is held in Constance to end the Schism
Death of Ladislas of Anjou-Durazzo, king of Naples: his sister Joan II becomes queen
Joan II of Naples disinherits Alfonso V of Aragon, and recalls Louis III of Anjou
Venice takes Brescia and Bergamo from Milan
Joan of Arc retakes Orléans from the English
Margery Kempe (c.1373–after 1438) starts dictating her Book

note: Death of Pope Martin V: Pope Eugene IV (Gabriele Condulmer) is elected. Council of Basle–Ferrara–Florence (1431–49) is summoned with the aim of ending the schism with the Byzantine church.
title: Charles VII is crowned king in Reims; Joan of Arc is executed in Rouen

Cosimo de’ Medici (the Elder) becomes the leader of the Medicean reggimento in Florence. Leon Battista Alberti (1404–1472) writes the Libri della famiglia in the Florentine vernacular. Death of Wladislaw II Jagello, king of Poland-Lithuania: his son Wladislaw III, 10 years old, becomes king of Poland, while Wladislaw’s younger brother, Casimir, is sent in Lithuania as royal lieutenant, and acclaimed grand duke by the Lithuanians

note: and defeat Alfonso V of Aragon at the naval battle of Ponza.
title: Conference of Arras: Charles VII and Philip the Good of Burgundy reconcile. Death of Joan II of Anjou, who has declared Louis III of Anjou’s brother, René, her heir to the crown of Naples; Filippo Maria Visconti and Genoa support René

container-title: Filippo Brunelleschi (1377–1446) completes the dome of the cathedral of Santa Maria del Fiore in Florence
title: Agreement of Basle: a section of the Hussites (the Utraquists) recognizes Sigismund of Luxembourg as king of Bohemia, while the Taborites do not
Death of Sigismund of Luxembourg, king of Bohemia and Hungary, and emperor
Albert (II) of Austria becomes king of Bohemia and Hungary, then of the Romans. The Pragmatic Sanction is issued in Bourges
Death of Albert II of Habsburg: his cousin Frederick is regent on behalf of Albert’s infant son, Ladislas the Posthumous; the Hungarian barons elect King Wladislaw III of Poland as Ladislas’s heir
at the court of Alfonso V of Aragon in Naples, among other works writes the De falso credita et ementita Constantini donatione
Frederick III of Habsburg is crowned king of the Romans
Alfonso V of Aragon conquers the kingdom of Naples; his wife, Queen Mary, remains in Aragon and rules the Iberian domains of the dynasty in his name

note: 1445–8 Charles VII reforms the French army.
title: Battle of Varna: the king of Hungary and Poland, Wladislaw III, is killed by the Ottomans, and his brother Casimir (IV) becomes king, reuniting Poland and Lithuania under his personal rule

publisher: son of Albert II of Habsburg
title: János Huniady is elected regent of Hungary on behalf of Ladislas Posthumous

The condottiere Francesco Sforza, having married in 1441 Bianca Maria Visconti, the sole heir to the duchy of Milan, becomes duke: while supported by the Milanese, he would never receive the imperial investiture to the duchy
Frederick III of Habsburg is crowned emperor in Rome (this is the last imperial coronation in Rome). 1452–4 Last war between Milan and Venice

container-title: Ladislas V
note: the Posthumous, becomes king of Hungary and Bohemia.
title: Fall of Byzantium at the hands of the Ottoman sultan Mehmed the Conqueror. Battle of Castillon and end of the Hundred Years War. Richard duke of York is nominated Defensor regni by Parliament, de facto replacing the increasingly unreliable Henry VI: the so-called War of the Roses between Lancaster and York for the crown of England begins
Death of John II of Castile: his son Henry IV becomes king. Peace of Lodi among Francesco Sforza, duke of Milan, and the republics of Venice and Florence

note: and all the minor Italian powers.
title: Italic League established among Milan
Death of Ladislas V, the Posthumous, of Hungary and Bohemia: all his dynastic domains are inherited by the emperor

note: Matthias Hunyadi (Corvinus), son of János (who died while freeing Belgrade from the Ottomans in 1456), becomes king of Hungary. The pro-Hussite George Podebrady becomes king of Bohemia.
title: Death of Alfonso V of Aragon: his son Ferdinand I (Ferrante) becomes king of Naples, while Alfonso’s brother John II of Aragon rules the Iberian domains and Sicily
The pro-Angevin Neapolitan barons rebel against King Ferrante

note: Death of Richard of York, presumptive heir of Henry VI: his son Edward (IV), earl of March, proclaims himself king.
title: Death of Charles VII of France and succession of Louis XI

The ‘League of the Bien Public’ among the dukes of Burgundy, Bourbon, and Brittany defies Louis XI of France; this crisis inaugurates a period of ruthless struggle between the king and his princely opponents
The Polish–Lithuanian Union annexes Prussia at the cost of the Teutonic Order
Death of Philip the Good of Burgundy and succession of Charles the Bold
Rebellion of the Castilian nobility led by King Henry IV’s siblings Alfonso and Isabella: Henry IV, who recovers his throne, is forced to nominate his sister Isabella as his heir

publisher: Matthias Corvinus becomes king of Hungary
title: Edward IV is captured by the Lancaster Isabella of Castile marries Ferdinand, heir to the Aragonese crown
Henry VI of England is back on the throne

publisher: Matthias Corvinus of Hungary and King George Podebrady of Bohemia
title: Battle of Tewkesbury: the winner, Edward IV, enters in London as king. Diet of Ratisbon: Frederick III recognizes King

note: finishes (presumably) the frescoes of the Camera picta in the castle of San Giorgio in Mantua.
title: Death of Henry IV of Castile: before dying, he divests his sister Isabella from the crown in favour of his daughter Joan
Matthias Corvinus, king of Hungary, marries Beatrice of Aragon, daughter of King Ferrante of Naples
Death of Charles the Bold of Burgundy in the battle of Nancy against the Swiss
The Pazzi conspiracy threatens the Medici hegemony in Florence

note: apart from Portugal and Navarra (which is incorporated into Castile in 1512).
title: Treaty of Truillo: at John II of Aragon’s death, his son Ferdinand, Isabella’s husband, becomes king. The Catholic kings Ferdinand and Isabella rule almost all of the Iberian kingdoms
An Ottoman expedition conquers Otranto, in the kingdom of Naples. Ivan III of Moscow defeats a Great Horde major campaign and ‘throws off the Mongol yoke’
Death of the Ottoman sultan Mehmed the Conqueror

note: son of Louis, and Margaret, daughter of Maximilian.
title: Peace of Arras between Louis XI of France and Maximilian of Habsburg, heir to the Burgundian dominions by the marriage with Mary, Duke Charles the Bold’s only heir; the agreement stipulates the marriage of Charles

author.literal: Death of Louis XI and succession of Charles VIII.

title: Death of Edward IV; his brother Richard (III) of Gloucester eliminates Edward’s two young sons and becomes king of England

note: Matthias Corvinus enters Vienna, defeating Emperor Frederick III. 1485–6 The so-called ‘Conspiracy of the Barons’ threatens the rule of King Ferrante of Naples.
title: Battle of Bosworth: Richard III is defeated by Henry Tudor, who becomes Henry VII of England
Publication of the Malleus maleficarum, the classic handbook of witch detection. c.1489 Philippe de Commynes (1447–1511) starts writing his Mémoires
Death of Matthias Corvinus, king of Hungary: he is succeeded not by his illegitimate son John, but by King Wladislaw of Bohemia, elected by the Hungarian diet
Charles VIII of France repudiates Margaret of Austria (daughter of Maximilian of Habsburg
Granada, the last Muslim outpost in Spain, is conquered by Ferdinand and Isabella; the Jews are expelled from all the kingdoms of the Catholic kings
Death of Charles VIII of France; his cousin Louis of Orléans becomes King Louis XII
The Swiss acquire de facto independence from the empire

note: Pedro Alvares Cabral (1467–1520) discovers what is now Brazil on behalf of the king of Portugal.
title: The French army definitively occupies the duchy of Milan; Duke Ludovico is taken prisoner to France
Isma’il becomes the first Safawid shah of Persia
Death of Isabella of Castile

author.literal: Pope Julius II (Giuliano della Rovere) commissions Donato Bramante

note: to begin the reconstruction of St Peter in Rome.
Michelangelo Buonarroti (1475–1564) starts painting the Sistine Chapel.
title: Establishment of the League of Cambrai between the papacy, France, Spain, and the empire against Venice
Death of Henry VII of England: his son Henry VIII becomes king. Battle of Agnadello: the army of the League of Cambrai defeates Venice

container-title: Desiderius Erasmus of Rotterdam (1466–1536) publishes In Praise of Folly
title: Pope Julius II dissolves the League of Cambrai and addresses his efforts, within the new Holy League, against Louis XII of France

note: defeats the League, but the French captain dies on the field.
title: Death of the Ottoman sultan Bayazed. Battle of Ravenna: the French army, led by Gaston de Foix

note: writes De principatibus (first printed edition, 1532). League of the Swiss Thirteen Cantons. Death of Pope Julius II: Leo X (Giovanni de’ Medici) becomes pope.

title: Battle of Tchaldiran between the Ottoman sultan Selim I and the Safawid shah Isma’il: Selim controls a strong frontier province along the border with Persia

Death of Louis XII of France: Francis I becomes king. Battle of Marignano: the French and Venetian armies (allied after dissolution of the previous leagues) defeat the Swiss, who controlled the duchy of Milan

note: is printed in Leuven. Erasmus of Rotterdam issues his Novum instrumentum (translation of the New Testament). The Orlando furioso by Ludovico Ariosto (1474–1533) is printed in Ferrara. 266 
title: Death of Ferdinand of Spain; his grandchild Charles of Habsburg becomes king. Utopia, by Thomas More
Ninety-five Theses written by Martin Luther. Mamluk Syria and Egypt are conquered by the Ottoman sultan Selim I

note: Hernán Cortés (1485–1547) lands in Mexico. Fernão de Magalhanes (1480–1521) leaves Spain for the journey that will circumnavigate the world.
title: Death of Maximilian I; his grandson Charles of Habsburg becomes Emperor Charles V
